items.title: pypi/release is out of date (commits to master are over a year old)
items.body:
The [last release](https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/releases/tag/v0.14.7) is over a year old, and the fix such as #312 (for #311) has not been released yet. I spent too much time debugging why this was still happening for me until I realized I wasn't actually looking at the code I thought I was running.

I added #331 to update that this package does work in newer versions of Python, but the tests have not been updated to support additional environments in awhile. I was looking at updating the travis config to have more complete support, but the testing matrix was looking rather large and I'm not sure if you actually would want the change I was making (I'm not sure what version of Python/frameworks you want to support testing against)

items.title: Add Person data to python logging without using a web framework
items.body:
This is a similar issue to #320 

I'm looking to add Person data to a desktop application with no explicit request object. I have tried injecting a custom attribute directly into the LogRecord with the code below, however no request object is coming through. The documentation is a little sparse on what a `request` object is when outside of the confines of a given web framework. My application is a desktop client application and I'm looking to log the USERNAME environment variable to Rollbar's People tracking functionality.

```python
old_factory = logging.getLogRecordFactory()

def record_factory(*args, **kwargs):
    record = old_factory(*args, **kwargs)
    record.request = {"rollbar_person": "some user"}
    return record

logging.setLogRecordFactory(record_factory)
```

Likewise, I have tried setting ```BASE_DATA_HOOK``` using the methodology in #320 and this additional snippet to the hook function:
```python
data["rollbar_person"] = "user id"
```

I feel like I'm missing something rudimentary.

items.title: 100% CPU and RAM when handling exception raised from itself
items.body:
Hi!

First of all: Thanks for a great library! Rollbar, and pyrollbar, has been a very useful tool for me in my work.

I recently tackled very pernicious problem at work. We had a situation where our servers would in rare occasions start hogging CPU at 100% and slowly run out of RAM.

This happened when we raised an exception from itself. Something that probably isn't very usual, or even correct, but it did happen by accident in a medium-big Django/Django Rest Framework codebase, where exception handlers got some wires crossed.

To illustrate, here's a crude view of the situation:

```python
def my_view(request):
    # do stuff
    raise Foo()

def request_dispatch(request):
    try:
        self.run_view(request)  # original exception raised here
    except Exception as exc:
        self.handle_exception(exc)

def handle_exception(self, exc):
        new_exc = wrap_exception(exc)  # In rare situations, this would return exc straight up
        raise new_exc from exc
```

Of course, one could argue that raising an exception from itself is a terribly bad idea - and probably it is!

But the main problem is that the `__cause__` attribute of exceptions allows for code to potentially traverse an infinite graph if there is a circular dependency in there.

This caused our servers to go down in production once, and caused us to spend a lot of time debugging.

The reason: Pyrollbar was unraveling the trace-chain, by following `exc.__cause__`. But since `exc.__cause__ == exc`, it would unravel forever, hogging CPU, and eating up RAM.

So, I implemented a fix here: https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/pull/317. It might not necessarily be the right/best way to fix it, but figured to put in a PR anyway.

Interestingly, Django has a similar problem, when `DEBUG = True`. And I just noticed that recently they patched it (see https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/29393 and https://github.com/django/django/blob/400ec5125ec32e3b18d267bbb4f3aab09d741ce4/django/views/debug.py#L401).

items.title: django-rest-framework: UnsupportedMediaType crashes post_exception_handler
items.body:
Hello,

we are happy users of rollbar but recently we came across the following problem:
When we use the following settings:
```
REST_FRAMEWORK = {
    'EXCEPTION_HANDLER': 'rollbar.contrib.django_rest_framework.post_exception_handler'
}
```
and `UnsupportedMediaType` error is raised, the request fails with 500 status instead of 415.

The problem is in the [line 21](https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/blob/master/rollbar/contrib/django_rest_framework/__init__.py#L21)
```python
context['request']._request.POST = context['request'].data
```
where the `data` attribute tries to read the data but these cannot be parsed as the media type is not supported.

For now, we created the following workaround:
```python
from rest_framework.exceptions import APIException, UnsupportedMediaType, ParseError
from rollbar.contrib.django_rest_framework import post_exception_handler, RestFrameworkExceptionHandler

def custom_exception_handler(exc: Union[Exception, APIException], context: dict) -> Response:
    # Call Rollbar's post exception handler first, to get the standard error response.
    try:
        return post_exception_handler(exc, context)
    except (UnsupportedMediaType, ParseError):
        return RestFrameworkExceptionHandler(exc, context)
```

But is there a proper way how to handle this?
With regards
Krystof

items.title: Ignore exceptions in Pyramid middleware?
items.body:
I have certain exceptions that I expect to happen and catch using an error view to produce a helpful response.  For example, something like this:

```python
@view_config(context=ExpiredTokenException)
def expired_token(context, request):
    return HTTPFound(request.resource_path(SIGNIN_URL))
```

Even though this error is handled, Rollbar sees the ExpiredTokenException in `request.exception` and reports the error to Rollbar.  (Which is somewhat [my fault](https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/pull/162))  I'd like a way to ignore these errors.  A few ideas:

* Have a request property to tell Rollbar to ignore it.  e.g., `request.ignore_exception`
* A configurable EXCEPTION_WHITELIST and EXCEPTION_BLACKLIST

I'm willing to do the legwork on this, but wanted to get some feedback first.

(I've tried doing `request.exception = None`in my error view, but Pyramid overrides it.)

items.title: Testing Slack integration
blocking handler doesn't work in rq
items.body:
I'm struggling to get rollbar (0.14.2) to work with [rq](http://python-rq.org/). In particular, I'm using [`django-rq`](https://github.com/rq/django-rq) which is just a convenient wrapper. With `django-rq` you can define your own custom exception handler function. I did that, with `settings.RQ_EXCEPTION_HANDLERS = ["songsearch.rq.peterbe_rollbar_exception_handler"]`. 

The function looks like this:

```python
def peterbe_rollbar_exception_handler(job, *exc_info):
    print("IN peterbe_rollbar_exception_handler")
    print("settings.ROLLBAR_ACCESS_TOKEN", settings.ROLLBAR["access_token"])
    print("JOB", repr(job))
    print("EXC_INFO", exc_info)
    rollbar.init(
        settings.ROLLBAR["access_token"],
        settings.ROLLBAR["environment"],
        handler="blocking",  # NOTE!!
    )
    job_info = job.to_dict()
    job_info["data"] = repr(job_info["data"])
    extra_data = {"job": job_info}
    payload_data = {
        "framework": "rq",
        "exception_handler": "peterbe_rollbar_exception_handler",
    }
    R = rollbar.report_exc_info(
        exc_info, extra_data=extra_data, payload_data=payload_data
    )
    print("R...")
    print(repr(R))
```

The details aren't particularly important. I can clean this up later. The messages just aren't sent. I put some print statements into [`rollbar/__init__.py`'s `_post_api` function](https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/blob/18b40e6b8c94864dc0832c8f617aa42f829fa2da/rollbar/__init__.py#L1365)
It now looks like this (the print statements are my only addition):

```python
def _post_api(path, payload_str, access_token=None):
    headers = {'Content-Type': 'application/json'}

    if access_token is not None:
        headers['X-Rollbar-Access-Token'] = access_token

    url = urljoin(SETTINGS['endpoint'], path)
    print("About to call transport.post", repr(transport))
    resp = transport.post(url,
                         data=payload_str,
                         headers=headers,
                         timeout=SETTINGS.get('timeout', DEFAULT_TIMEOUT),
                         verify=SETTINGS.get('verify_https', True))
    print("RESP:", repr(resp))

    return _parse_response(path, SETTINGS['access_token'], payload_str, resp)
```

I get, in my `stdout`:
```
About to call transport.post <module 'rollbar.lib.transport' from '/Users/peterbe/virtualenvs/songsearch/lib/python3.5/site-packages/rollbar/lib/transport.py'>
```
But it never prints the line `print("RESP:", repr(resp))` because it just hangs on the call to `transport.post()`. 

I wonder if it's because, even with `handler="blocking"` it uses the threading code here: https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/blob/18b40e6b8c94864dc0832c8f617aa42f829fa2da/rollbar/lib/transport.py#L5 which doesn't work in `rq`, because, I don't know, threads.

items.title: blocking handler doesn't work in most basic example
items.body:
I was trying to get [`django-rq`](https://github.com/rq/django-rq) with `rollbar` but instead of creating my own worker using [this tip](https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/blob/18b40e6b8c94864dc0832c8f617aa42f829fa2da/rollbar/contrib/rq/__init__.py#L2-L30) I defined my own custom worker class, which inside the `__init__`, calls `rollbar.init(...)` and set a custom exception handler function. 

I thought I had everything working but messages were never received. The instructions in `rollbar.contrib.rq.__init__` warns that you need to use `handler="blocking"` because (the default) `handler="thread"` doesn't work there. 

So I tested like this:

```
>>> import os
>>> access_token=os.environ.get('ROLLBAR_ACCESS_TOKEN')
>>> assert access_token
>>> import rollbar
>>> rollbar.init(access_token, 'development')
>>> try:
...   a=b
... except Exception:
...   rollbar.report_exc_info()
...
```
That worked! I got an email from Rollbar within seconds and the exception was in my dashboard. 

Now, exact same thing but with `handler="blocking"`:

```
>>> import os
>>> access_token=os.environ.get('ROLLBAR_ACCESS_TOKEN')
>>> assert access_token
>>> import rollbar
>>> rollbar.init(access_token, 'development', handler='blocking')
>>> try:
...   c=d
... except Exception:
...   rollbar.report_exc_info()
...
```

Nothing happened :(

items.title: Ability to set requests.Session() pool size
items.body:
Currently in our app we're doing the following as during startup some of our services emit a lot of (important) debug data at a rate that exceeds the default request pool size, so this is our workaround (in our custom `logging.Handler` rollbar wrapper)

It would be great if we could pass something like this through the `rollbar.init` params. I can create a PR if you guys think this is something you want.

```python
import requests
import rollbar.lib.transport as tr
tr._session().mount('https://', requests.adapters.HTTPAdapter(max_retries=3, pool_connections=10, pool_maxsize=20))
tr._session().mount('http://', requests.adapters.HTTPAdapter(max_retries=3, pool_connections=10, pool_maxsize=20))
```

Perhaps this can be done on Rollbar server-side. E.g, we could detect that an event happens exactly in the same (stack frame, process, thread) and "merge" (or link) the events into one?

items.body:
Hello, 

When using `rollbar==0.13.18` with `django==1.11.11` and passing rollbar via LOGGER, scrub_fields doesn't come as a list; it comes as `logging.config.ConvertingList`, so in the result dict_merge fall to make a copy of variable and return string `'<Uncopyable obj:...'` instead of a list.

I see here two possible solutions:

The first is to change dict_merge to correctly process types inherited from list/dict in the case where copy.deepcopy failed.

The second is to obviously handle scrub_fields in rollbar.init().

items.title: Better Werkzeug Support
items.body:
I realize this is my fault for using Werkzeug in my application directly, so feel free to close this if first-class werkzeug support isn't a priority for rollbar. 

It was pretty painful to get requests to get sent to rollbar when using werkzeug (to the point where I had to monkey-patch rollbar to get things working), so I thought I'd document here how I got it working.

The main problem was that I subclassed the werkzeug BaseRequest (as recommended on line 111 [here](https://github.com/pallets/werkzeug/blob/master/werkzeug/wrappers.py)) in order to use some of their extra request wrappers:

```
from werkzeug.wrappers import (
    BaseRequest,
    AuthorizationMixin,
    CommonRequestDescriptorsMixin)
from werkzeug.contrib.wrappers import (
    JSONRequestMixin, RoutingArgsRequestMixin)


class Request(
        BaseRequest,
        AuthorizationMixin,
        CommonRequestDescriptorsMixin,
        JSONRequestMixin,
        RoutingArgsRequestMixin):
    pass
```

This doesn't work with rollbar, because of line 64 of `rollbar/__init__.py`:

```
from werkzeug.wrappers import Request as WerkzeugRequest
```

And line 1004:

```
    if WerkzeugRequest and isinstance(request, WerkzeugRequest):
        return _build_werkzeug_request_data(request)
```

Basically, rollbar is doing `isinstance` on `Request` rather than `BaseRequest`, so my custom request object fails the check and `_build_request_data` returns `None`.

I think the solution is fairly easy - either switch from `isinstance` to ducktyping, or check for `werkzeug.BaseRequest`.

items.title: Incorrect _send_payload_tornado implementation
items.body:
The [`_send_payload_tornado `](https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/blob/b46d08e47cf8fb23ff4db287e2a88282b1f8593a/rollbar/__init__.py#L1270) implementation is incorrect because `_post_api_tornado ` coroutine is called like a regular function. The consequences are:

1. [`log.exception`](https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/blob/b46d08e47cf8fb23ff4db287e2a88282b1f8593a/rollbar/__init__.py#L1272) code never works.
2. Rollbar is flooded with `Future %r exception was never retrieved: %s (/usr/local/lib/python*/site-packages/tornado/concurrent.py:__del__)` errors in case of an error calling the Rollbar API.

There are several ways to fix it:
1. `yield _post_api_tornado`.
2. Use [`IOLoop.spawn_callback`](http://www.tornadoweb.org/en/stable/ioloop.html#tornado.ioloop.IOLoop.spawn_callback).
3. Use [`IOLoop.add_future`](http://www.tornadoweb.org/en/stable/ioloop.html#tornado.ioloop.IOLoop.add_future).

items.title: Django/python logs don't show up when running app locally
Regression in 0.13.17 when `payload_data` is supplied without `'body'`
items.body:
Hi--we recently had to downgrade to 0.13.16 due to a KeyError in [`__init__.py` line 630](https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/blob/v0.13.17/rollbar/__init__.py#L630):

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/rollbar/__init__.py", line 393, in report_exc_info
    return _report_exc_info(exc_info, request, extra_data, payload_data, level=level)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/rollbar/__init__.py", line 630, in _report_exc_info
    if payload_data and payload_data['body'] and payload_data['body']['trace']:
KeyError: 'body'
```

The problem is that we're calling `_report_exc_info` with `payload_data` that doesn't have a `'body'` key, and also a multi-level trace chain. My understanding from the docs is that this should be allowed--`payload_data` is supposed to override default keys, so it should use the default `body` if we don't supply one.

items.title: Logging in celery outside of flask context?
items.body:
Hello, I got sent here by Rollbar support. We currently use rollbar in both flask (request context) and celery (worker context) and we get exceptions thrown by the rollbar package.

This is how we setup celery:
```
@worker_init.connect
@beat_init.connect
def initialize_rollbar(**kwargs):
    del kwargs

    rollbar.init(
        config['ROLLBAR_TOKEN'],
        config['ENVIRONMENT'],
        root=config['API_PATH'],
        allow_logging_basic_config=False,
    )

    def base_data_hook(request, data):
        del request

        data['framework'] = 'celery'
    rollbar.BASE_DATA_HOOK = base_data_hook
```

Running a log.warning() inside a celery task correctly logs the error to rollbar but it also floods our local logs with this exception:
```
*testexception*

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/moodh/.pyenv/versions/3.6.3/envs/flow/lib/python3.6/site-packages/rollbar/__init__.py", line 756, in _add_person_data
    person_data = _build_person_data(request)
  File "/Users/moodh/.pyenv/versions/3.6.3/envs/flow/lib/python3.6/site-packages/rollbar/__init__.py", line 770, in _build_person_data
    if hasattr(request, 'rollbar_person'):
  File "/Users/moodh/.pyenv/versions/3.6.3/envs/flow/lib/python3.6/site-packages/werkzeug/local.py", line 347, in __getattr__
    return getattr(self._get_current_object(), name)
  File "/Users/moodh/.pyenv/versions/3.6.3/envs/flow/lib/python3.6/site-packages/werkzeug/local.py", line 306, in _get_current_object
    return self.__local()
  File "/Users/moodh/.pyenv/versions/3.6.3/envs/flow/lib/python3.6/site-packages/flask/globals.py", line 37, in _lookup_req_object
    raise RuntimeError(_request_ctx_err_msg)
RuntimeError: Working outside of request context.

This typically means that you attempted to use functionality that needed
an active HTTP request.  Consult the documentation on testing for
information about how to avoid this problem.
```

It seems to try to load flask (since it's importable) and inject people data (there's no request to get), but since the code tries to access flask's request context it complains that it isn't in a request context.

Can I somehow turn off the flask parts when we're not actually inside flask? Maybe use a celery request instead (`task.request`).

items.title: API error: Invalid format. data.body.trace.frames is missing and it is required. data.body.trace.exception.class is missing and it is required.
items.body:
We're getting this error since upgrading from `0.13.11` to `0.13.13`.
(this issue https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/issues/197 looks similar)

We're using the django rollbar handler and not the middleware. This happens not for all but for some exceptions sent to rollbar.
I noticed that the `body` payload that is sent includes both `trace` and `trace_chain` but the rollbar documentation says, to only send one ("// Required: "trace", "trace_chain", "message", or "crash_report" (exactly one)"). The `trace` part for those errors seem to always look like:

```
      "trace": {
        "exception": {
          "description": "meaningful description here"
        }
      },
```

*edit:*
this is how we create the handler:
```
        'rollbar': {
            'level': 'WARNING',
            'class': 'rollbar.logger.RollbarHandler',
            'history_level': 'WARNING',
        },
```

We downgraded for now. Let me know if any more information can help you.

items.title: Rollbar is raising errors when running Django permission tests
items.body:
I have some simple permission tests to make sure users can not access certain sections of the site. For example:

```
from django.test import TestCase, Client
from django.core.urlresolvers import reverse

class PermissionsTestCase(TestCase):
    def test_logged_out_list_view(self):
        client = Client()
        response = client.get(reverse('list_view'))
        self.assertEqual(response.status_code, 403)
```

The tests run fine (logged out users can not access `list_view`) however I am getting `PermissionDenied` errors in rollbar. This is odd because the [test client shouldn't raise this exception](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/topics/testing/tools/#exceptions).

Installed with the middleware per the instructions on Django 1.9.13. Let me know what other information would be useful in debugging this.

items.title: Chained exceptions are not properly shown in Rollbar GUI
items.body:
Not clear to me why this is a `pyrollbar` issue, but was sent here by the support.

Rollbar exception reporting for chained exceptions should follow the method described in [PEP 3134](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3134/#enhanced-reporting), to describe the relationship between chained exceptions (i.e. cause and context).

Currently the exceptions are displayed without any clarification on _how_ they are related in the chain, and also in opposite order of how the default Python exception handler displays exceptions (which, of course, makes the lack of description of the relationship between exceptions even more problematic).

Thanks!

items.title: Django request body can include sensitive data
items.body:
Post requests can include sensitive data in the request body. Sensitive POST params can be scrubbed from the request.POST attributes but not from the request body itself.

I think this works for other frameworks (werkzeug, bottle) because the body is only included if it's JSON and can then be scrubbed, but the django body is just a string.

items.title: Infinite loop in Twisted handler
items.body:
Certain types of network errors will cause pyrollbar to get into a loop when using the Twisted handler. One such type of network error is to point pyrollbar's endpoint somewhere with an invalid or self-signed certificate.

Basically, our treq network call reports an error into Twisted logging system that doesn't get recognized as an internal error.  As a result, the observer ends up calling report_exc_info which gets reported into Twisted's logging system and so on.

If you're a Rollbar employee, the easiest way to cause this error to get trapped in the reactor is to try and send an error to your dev vm using the HTTPS endpoint. Twisted doesn't like self-signed certs.

items.title: Twisted should not install log handler automatically
items.body: Rollbar automatically installs the log observer for twisted upon import.  This is a massive issue if you never initialize rollbar or if the initialization fails. The log observer should be added *after* you call `rollbar.init(handler='twisted', **settings.ROLLBAR)` so that you can verify it will work before sending messages to the observer.  If you do not initialize rollbar the observer will receive messages but will err out until it completely blocks the twisted loop.

This should be configurable in the settings and support both direct API calls (`report_message`) as well as `report_exc_info`

items.title: Support recording deployments via pyrollbar
items.body: Notifiers in other libraries support this so it should be included in this library. The basic idea is to have a library function that makes reporting to this API easy: https://rollbar.com/docs/api/deploys/#record-create-a-deploy

items.title: rollbar obscures source exception in `raise ... from ...`
items.body:
Python's `raise ... from ...` syntax allows reraising a different without obscuring the original exception:

As an example:

```
In [1]: def f():
   ...:     raise ValueError
   ...:

In [2]: try:
   ...:     f()
   ...: except ValueError as e:
   ...:     raise KeyError from e
   ...:
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-913ffaaf7120> in <module>()
      1 try:
----> 2     f()
      3 except ValueError as e:

<ipython-input-1-5abf6c8b606a> in f()
      1 def f():
----> 2     raise ValueError

ValueError:

The above exception was the direct cause of the following exception:

KeyError                                  Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-913ffaaf7120> in <module>()
      2     f()
      3 except ValueError as e:
----> 4     raise KeyError from e

KeyError:
```

However, it seems like Rollbar doesn't display the source exception traceback at all. This makes debugging harder.

(I don't know enough about how Rollbar works to know for sure if this is a client issue, but figured I'd report it here.)

Thanks!

items.title: pyramid integration not correctly parsing boolean settings
items.body:
If you have boolean settings values in a paste config file, they will not be turned into booleans when parsing. For example, given the following config:

```
rollbar.debug = false
rollbar.verify_https = false
```

rollbar.SETTINGS will end up containing `'false'` instead of `False` for the above values.

items.title: Message formatting
items.body:
Is there any reason why message formatting isn't done when emitting exception type messages
In `logger.py`, `emit` method:
```
          message = record.msg
          extra_data = {
              'args': record.args,
```
This is fine for "message" type events, but for "exception" type events, we can use the full message - record.getMessage(), because the merging algorithm doesn't rely on that string.

items.title: Exception in message logging kills application thread until reboot.
items.body:
# Summary

We encountered a UnicodeDecodeError when the logger was interpolating a message. The corrupted message was stored in thread-local memory. Therefore every subsequent request to that thread that triggered a logging call would attempt to read that corrupted message and raise the same exception, effectivly taking down the application until manually rebooted.
## Details
### Steps
1. A logger call tries to log a message that has unicode in the arguments.
2. log message is put in threadlocal history by rollbar 
3. logger raises UnicodeDecodeError
4. Another request hits the same thread, triggers a logger call
5. logger attempts to read history 
6. logger triggers same exception from the bad message
### Versions:
- Django 1.8.13
- Python 2.7.11
- pyrollbar 0.13.3
### Environment
- Heroku w/ gunicorn
### Logging config
- Using the django rollbarmiddleware
- Using the rollbar log handler
# Culprit:

Line that triggers the exception: https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/blob/047ddabf7dda5b20b7542da98bee4ba3c8967600/rollbar/logger.py#L164
Line that pulls in corrupted message: https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/blob/047ddabf7dda5b20b7542da98bee4ba3c8967600/rollbar/logger.py#L30
# Example Stacktrace (with some ommited data)

items.title: Dozens of errors per second in tornado handler
items.body:
We used rollbar with default threaded handler for tornado application for a long while and recently have switched to tornado handler and faced with the following error after some time (2-3 days). Server logs were full of errors with frequency several dozens per second. The application eats about 5-6 Gigs of memory:

```
Sep 09 02:18:42:  ERROR:tornado.application:Future exception was never retrieved: Traceback (most recent call last):
Sep 09 02:18:42:    File "/env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tornado/gen.py", line 1014, in run
Sep 09 02:18:42:      yielded = self.gen.throw(*exc_info)
Sep 09 02:18:42:    File "/env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/rollbar/__init__.py", line 1167, in _post_api_tornado
Sep 09 02:18:42:      request_timeout=SETTINGS.get('timeout', DEFAULT_TIMEOUT)
Sep 09 02:18:42:    File "/env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tornado/gen.py", line 1008, in run
Sep 09 02:18:42:      value = future.result()
Sep 09 02:18:42:    File "/env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tornado/concurrent.py", line 232, in result
Sep 09 02:18:42:      raise_exc_info(self._exc_info)
Sep 09 02:18:42:    File "<string>", line 3, in raise_exc_info
Sep 09 02:18:42:  HTTPError: HTTP 599: Timeout
```

We are handling errors via logging errors:

``` python
import logging.handlers

import rollbar.logger

from tornado import log
from tornado.httputil import HTTPServerRequest

class TornadoRollbarHandler(rollbar.logger.RollbarHandler):
    def emit(self, record):
        if record.name == 'tornado.application':
            if len(record.args) >= 2:
                request = record.args[1]
                if isinstance(request, HTTPServerRequest):
                    record.request = request

        return super(TornadoRollbarHandler, self).emit(record)


rollbar.init(**{
    'enabled': False,
    'access_token': 'xxx',
    'environment': ENVIRONMENT,
    'handler': 'tornado',
    'allow_logging_basic_config': False,
})

rollbar_handler = TornadoRollbarHandler(history_level=logging.INFO)
rollbar_handler.setLevel(logging.ERROR)
rollbar_handler.addFilter(ExcludeFilter('tornado.access'))
logging.root.addHandler(rollbar_handler)
```

python==2.7.6
tornado==4.3.0
rollbar==0.13.2

items.title: Support new Django 1.10 middleware API
items.body:
Django 1.10 introduced a new middleware API: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.10/topics/http/middleware/

`MIDDLEWARE_CLASSES` is deprecated in favor of `MIDDLEWARE`.

Instructions for upgrading the middleware are at:
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.10/topics/http/middleware/#upgrading-pre-django-1-10-style-middleware

The Travis CI configuration is already testing vs. Django 1.10. However, the Django example needs to be updated to use the new api.

items.title: [Django] Can't have model classes as whitelisted_types in settings.py
items.body:
Because the `whitelisted_types` is expected to be a list of `Type`s, we currently can't have model classes whitelisted in Django. The configuration is in `settings.py` and at this point it's not possible to import model classes.

My current solution is to list them as strings and have a singleton class that when instantiated will read those strings and convert them to types before calling the `rollbar.init` function. I instantiate this singleton in the wsgi.py file so that it's done before the `rollbar.contrib.django.middleware.RollbarNotifierMiddleware` can be called, otherwise the middleware would call `rollback.init` first without the `whitelisted_types` list being converted.
## settings.py

``` python
ROLLBAR = {
    'access_token': ACCESS_TOKEN,
    'environment': ENVIRONMENT,
    'branch': 'master/',
    'root': ROOT_PATH,
    'whitelisted_types': (
        ('application.models', 'AModel'),
        ('application.models', 'AnotherModel'),
    )
}
```
## rollbar_singleton.py

``` python
import rollbar
import sys

from django.conf import settings
from importlib import import_module


class Rollbar:
    ''' This is a singleton class meant to instantiate the rollbar service only once.
        To use it, simply use the following:
        from services.rollbar_singleton import Rollbar
        Rollbar.get_instance().report(...)
    '''
    class __Rollbar:
        def __init__(self):
            self.rollbar = rollbar

            # Transform the whitelisted tuples into types
            whitelisted_types_tuples = settings.ROLLBAR['whitelisted_types']

            imported_modules = {}
            whitelisted_types = []
            for module, class_name in whitelisted_types_tuples:
                imported_module = imported_modules.get(module)
                if not imported_module:
                    imported_module = import_module(module)
                    imported_modules[module] = imported_module

                imported_class = getattr(imported_module, class_name, None)
                if not imported_class:
                    continue
                whitelisted_types.append(imported_class)

            extra_configuration = {
                'locals': {
                    'whitelisted_types': whitelisted_types,
                }
            }

            self.rollbar.init(
                settings.ROLLBAR["access_token"],
                settings.ROLLBAR["environment"],
                **extra_configuration
            )

        def report(self, exc_info, request=None, extra_data=None, payload_data=None):
            return self.rollbar.report_exc_info(exc_info, request, extra_data, payload_data)

    __instance = None

    @classmethod
    def get_instance(cls):
        if not Rollbar.__instance:
            Rollbar.__instance = Rollbar.__Rollbar()

        return Rollbar.__instance
```
## wsgi.py

``` python
...
# Call get_instance to instantiate rollbar with correct settings.
from services.rollbar_singleton import Rollbar
Rollbar.get_instance()
```

This solution works fine but I'd rather have something less complicated where [SerializableTransform](https://github.com/rollbar/pyrollbar/blob/371da18384e2b1fd4e20a36a5bba90b91df6ee88/rollbar/lib/transforms/serializable.py#L16) would be the one taking care of transforming strings into types when being instantiated.

``` python
class SerializableTransform(Transform):
    def __init__(self, safe_repr=True, whitelist_types=None):
        super(SerializableTransform, self).__init__()
        self.safe_repr = safe_repr
        self.whitelist = set()
        for whitelist_type in whitelist_types:
            if isinstance(whitelist_type, str):
                # The convert_string_to_type needs to be implemented
                whitelist_type = convert_string_to_type(whitelist_type)
            self.whitelist.add(whitelist_types)
```

I'm open for comments and suggestions if you have a better solution.

items.title: Logging handler doesn't correctly format error message
items.body:
I'm using the Rollbar `logging` framework handler. I noticed that I'm getting a lot of warnings logged from my Django project with the message "Not Found: %s". On looking at the referenced line of Django source, I see that it is

``` python
            logger.warning('Not Found: %s', request.path,
                        extra={
                            'status_code': 404,
                            'request': request
                        })
```

On looking at the [logging docs](https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#logging.debug), I see that that second argument is supposed to be merged in to the first argument. This is what happens by the file logging handler -- my log files show the correct messages ("Not Found: /wp-login.php" for example). I haven't looked at the Rollbar source but it seems to me that this could be a bug there; an incomplete implementation of these logging calls.

items.title: Log Django 404s using a separate middleware that hooks in to process_response
items.body:
Howdy,

First - thanks for supporting and maintaining this library. Overall, Rollbar has worked out well for our Django site.

We're having trouble accurately reporting 404s, however. We're using [Wagtail](http://wagtail.io/), a Django-based CMS. Wagtail has a `redirects` middleware which is almost identical to [Django's contrib redirects](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.10/ref/contrib/redirects/) middleware.

Both middlewares use `process_response` to catch responses with 404 error codes and check to see if a user-defined redirect is available for them.

If your view still throws a `Http404` exception, however, Rollbar's middleware will see and report the exception _before_ any other middleware's `process_response` method has an opportunity to redirect the response. This happens regardless of the middleware order.

Because of this, our Rollbar dashboard has a ton of 404 warnings reported, but only a minority of them are valid - many are caught by the redirect middleware.

I was looking for solutions. It looks like Sentry solves this problem by providing a separate middleware for logging 404s and putting it at the top of the middleware stack: https://docs.getsentry.com/hosted/clients/python/integrations/django/#logging

We're going to keep using Rollbar to log 404s, even though our 404 logging data is noisy. But it would be great if there was some way I could accurately report 404s from our Django app.

Thanks.
